title: Compiling files can write almost empty useless(?) rlib files

labels.name: C-cleanup
labels.description: Category: PRs that clean code up or issues documenting cleanup.

labels.name: A-linkage
labels.description: Area: linking into static, shared libraries and binaries

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Reproduce:
1. Setup some tracking machinery (ETW on windows, for example)
2. compile `fn main(){}` with `rustc empty.rs -Clto=yes` (lto flag needed, without it files didn't created. Maybe other flags will work too)
3. Files like `libminiz_oxide-9633500de6d1ff03.rlib.temp-archive-7378fd5.a` will be created in temp directory, later moved to `libminiz_oxide-9633500de6d1ff03.rlib`. They will be deleted later.

Those files will be 8 bytes long (header only without content, i guess).

`members` here will be empty, but files still written:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/cad92b4c979760b088ffd18e6c89801668c944f2/compiler/rustc_codegen_llvm/src/back/archive.rs#L402-L409

This can be refactored to skip writing this files if members empty.

tested on 02-05-23 x86_64-pc-windows-msvc nightly

@rustbot label: +T-compiler +A-linkage +C-cleanup
